docs.snippet: The most striking change this season was the amount of innovative fabrics and embellishment....
docs.lead_paragraph: THE final day of Fashion Week felt a bit like a dash for the last plane out of Lisbon, if you know what I mean. Everyone wore very tight expressions. The journalists heading to London were already in the transit lounge. Still, the day's shows held some delights: Ralph Lauren's beautifully rendered Deco glamour and subplot of a Chinese retail assault; L'Wren Scott's Gauguin colors and a pitch, from both Ms. Scott and Francisco Costa of Calvin Klein, for short hemlines. Skirt lengths have generally been below the knees or to the ankles.
docs.abstract: The most striking change this season was the amount of innovative fabrics and embellishment.

docs.snippet: How did studios manage to find audiences for the adult films competing in this season's race for Oscar?...
docs.lead_paragraph: We've wondered how ticket sales affect Oscar campaigning all season long; films certainly get a boost from a nomination, perhaps even more so than a victory. The Los Angeles Times takes a close look at what could be either an anomaly or a harbinger in this year's crop of best picture nominees: even if they don't take home a little gold man, most are poised to be box office champs.
docs.abstract: How did studios manage to find audiences for the adult films competing in this season's race for Oscar?

headline.main: Movies for Grown-Ups Find an Audience

docs.snippet: Nick Offerman, who plays the lushly mustachioed, world-weary boss on "Parks and Recreation," talks about his surprising choice for best picture, his (equally surprising) love for dance and street art and his Oscar night plans....
docs.lead_paragraph: Hey, have you noticed our spiffy new interactive Oscar ballot, winking suggestively at you over on the right side of the screen? Go ahead, fill it out! In the lead-up to the big day, the Bagger has asked some well-known folks to join you in picking the most Oscar-worthy films and performances, and we'll be talking to some of them about their choices. First up: Nick Offerman, best known for playing the lushly mustachioed, world-weary boss on "Parks and Recreation" -- one of the Bagger's favorites -- where he occasionally stars opposite his wife, Megan Mullally.
docs.abstract: Nick Offerman, who plays the lushly mustachioed, world-weary boss on "Parks and Recreation," talks about his surprising choice for best picture, his (equally surprising) love for dance and street art and his Oscar night plans.

headline.main: Oscar Picks, Courtesy of the Man Behind Ron Swanson

docs.snippet: The app, available for 99 cents on iTunes, offers live video streams from more than two dozen cameras arranged in various spots backstage at the Kodak Theater....
docs.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES- ABC, working feverishly to improve the digital components of this year's Oscar telecast, unveiled a "backstage pass" app on Friday for iPad, iPhone and iPod touch users. Ho-hum, you say, another app. We're worn out with app mania too, but this one is notable partly because it is designed to be used while you are also watching the show.
docs.abstract: The app, available for 99 cents on iTunes, offers live video streams from more than two dozen cameras arranged in various spots backstage at the Kodak Theater.

headline.main: A Backstage Oscars Pass From ABC
